Triggering Event: "Checking his watch, he sighed as another shift ended without a word of thanks from his fellow nurses. He opened his locker to find a note left by his wife reminding him to pick up milk - again. Bitterness welled up in him as he realized she didn't even bother to ask if he'd be too tired after back-to-back twelve-hour shifts."
Generated Assessment: When I checked my watch for the 12th time that day, I couldn't help but feel frustrated with my coworkers. It was clear they were all busy, but it seemed like none of them would even acknowledge me. I tried to brush it off, thinking maybe they just weren't in the mood. But then I noticed that every time I asked one of them about what we were doing next, they'd simply stare at me before turning back to their work. I started to wonder if there was something going on that I wasn't aware of—maybe someone was upset about something? Or perhaps they were dealing with personal issues that made them distracted? I decided to take a closer look around the hospital, hoping to find some clue. As I walked past each room, I caught glimpses of patients who seemed to be struggling. One woman was crying softly while her husband held her hand; another had been bedridden for days, and now looked more exhausted than ever. A third patient was clearly scared, clinging to her mother’s arm as she tried to reassure her. It dawned on me that maybe these patients were the reason everyone was so short-tempered today. Maybe the stress of working long hours was making people irritable. I thought about how my own life was complicated lately – between caring for my elderly parents and dealing with my sister's health struggles, I felt overwhelmed most days. Was it possible that others were facing similar challenges? Why did nobody seem to care about us

Triggering Event: He watched them from his usual table at the bistro, his wife's favorite spot. The couple laughed too loudly, their hands entwined over the candlelit table. He felt a pang in his chest, not hunger but something else. The woman bore a striking resemblance to his late wife. As they left, she turned and caught his gaze. She smiled sympathetically, but it only fueled his jealousy, burning like the stove he'd been standing at just hours ago.
Generated Assessment: Fuck that shit! What if I get up and walk out right now? Maybe I'll leave my chair at the bar, walk into the kitchen, grab a plate of food, and storm back to the table where those two are sitting. What if they don't recognize me? What if she doesn't notice me staring? What if... what if... what if... Why the fuck am I thinking this way? I've got work tomorrow, and I'm still recovering from my hangover. But I can't shake off these thoughts. I feel like I'm going to lose my temper, start yelling at them for being so loud, or worse, maybe even try to hit them for making me think about her. Ugh, I need to get myself together. I'm starting to sound crazy, even to myself. What if I go back there? What if I say something stupid? What if... ugh, stop it, you fucking idiot! How did I let myself get so worked up over nothing? It's probably because I haven't had enough sleep. No, wait, it's because I know exactly why I'm feeling this way. That woman looks exactly like my late wife. And she's smiling at me. What if she invites herself over to our table? What if she asks me how I'm doing? What if she starts talking about her job? What if she tells me something about her life that reminds me of my wife? Ugh, I hate this.

Triggering Event: He watched her from his usual table at the café, nursing his coffee as she laughed freely with her friends. She was his age, perhaps even a year older, but her eyes sparkled with an energy he hadn't felt in decades. He noticed the expensive watch on her wrist, the designer bag by her side. His gaze drifted to his own worn-out shoes, the uniform he'd been wearing for years. When she stood up to leave, he saw the discreet 'L' engraved on her ring. A lifelong learner, she had once told him, not a wife or lover. Yet, envy gnawed at him nonetheless, as it always did when he saw her living the life he'd once envisioned for himself.
Generated Assessment: **Ugh, why does everyone get what they want? Why can't I have this life too?** I've seen people like her before, so many times. They come into my life, laugh, smile, and then disappear just like magic. It's infuriating. Even if I'm happy, I still feel left behind. I wonder how long it takes for them to forget about me, to move on to someone new. Does anyone ever remember me? They're all so lucky, while I'm stuck here, watching them live their dreams. I see her now, laughing and smiling, completely carefree. What would it be like to experience that joy again? To feel confident, to wear clothes that fit well, to hold hands with someone who cares? I'm tired of feeling invisible. The world moves forward, leaving me behind. Everyone gets what they want except me. Maybe I'll never understand why some people are so much happier than me. **Why do I always seem to miss out?** It's frustrating when I try to talk to them, but they don't notice me. Or maybe they do notice, but they're polite anyway. Like, "Oh, you're here." Yeah, I am. But no one wants to hear my problems or listen to my stories anymore. I'm just another face in the crowd. If I could turn back time, I'd choose a different path. I'd be the one with the designer watch and the stylish outfit

Triggering Event: She woke up with a tightness in her chest, heart pounding like a kick drum against her ribs. The clock read 5:30 AM; too early for the city to stir outside her window. Her breath hitched as she remembered why: today was the anniversary of his funeral. She had an interview scheduled for 9 AM, but the looming deadline did little to quell the anxious knot twisting in her stomach. As she reached for her phone to check messages, it slipped from her sweat-dampened hand, clattering onto the hardwood floor. The sudden noise echoed through the empty apartment, a stark reminder of the silence that had become her constant companion since he was taken.
Generated Assessment: She's been trying to get back into the workforce after losing him, but every day feels like a struggle. She wakes up to this tightness, and it's like the universe is reminding her of what she's lost—of how much time has passed, of how far behind she is. It doesn't help that she got an email from HR yesterday about the job interview. They wanted me to reschedule because the last one was canceled due to some sort of "family emergency." But I know why they cancelled it—the day before he died. If only I could turn back the clock, if only things were different. But life goes on, and she needs to go on. So she gets ready, forces herself out the door, and heads to the office. On her way there, she passes by the park where we used to walk together. The same park now fills her mind with memories of our last conversation, where he told me he wasn't feeling well and would see me later. He never came home. The sound of birds chirping and children playing turns into a cacophony of grief. She quickens her pace, but it does nothing to ease the ache. By the time she reaches the office, her hands are shaking, and she can barely look anyone in the eye. She takes a deep breath and steps inside, hoping to find some semblance of normalcy. Triggering Event:
Scenario:
She was juggling charts at her bustling clinic, each patient's life hanging silently in her aged yet steady hands. Her pager buzzed insistently; it was the ER, a car accident victim en route, critical condition. She felt a familiar chill of responsibility, her mind racing with possible diagnoses. Today was supposed to be her light day, but there were no light days anymore, not since he'd gone. She took a deep breath, steeling herself for another marathon shift under the unblinking gaze of the clock.
Generated Assessment: **It's always something** *What if that guy gets hit by a bus? What if she has a heart attack while driving home?* Her anxiety spiked as she checked every chart, searching for signs of distress. The doctors' eyes met hers, and they shared a look of solidarity, both knowing that this patient needed them now more than ever. "Let's move him to room 3," one doctor said, his voice firm but gentle. "We need to get an ECG running." "I'll prep the IV line," another chimed in, her hands moving swiftly as she worked. As I watched her, I couldn't help but think about how much I wish she wasn’t so busy. *But what if she had just taken off work today? What if she’d decided to stay home and enjoy a quiet morning instead?* The thought sent a pang through me, and suddenly I felt overwhelmed by my own worries. If only I could take some of her stress away, just for a moment. But then again, what if she didn't want my help? What if she saw it as an intrusion? I sighed inwardly, pushing aside my doubts. It wouldn't change anything, anyway. This is her job, after all. Yet, I couldn't shake the feeling that somehow I was missing out, that I should be here too, supporting her in whatever way I could. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

After a long day in the lab, she returns home to find dinner leftovers still on the table, untouched by her husband. She'd asked him earlier that week to start handling meal clean-up since she's been working late nights to meet an upcoming deadline. Tears threaten as she realizes he hasn't noticed or cared about her request. She feels unseen and unappreciated, the familiar weight of loneliness settling heavy on her shoulders.

Triggering Event: She found his old lab coat in her cabinet, still stained with his carelessness. Her grip tightened around it as she threw it into the incinerator, hating every thread that once belonged to him.
Generated Assessment: She is absolutely horrible for even having this lab coat in her possession. The fact that she didn't immediately throw it away when he left was just another evidence of her disgusting behavior. It's clear she doesn't want me anywhere near her, and I'm going to make sure she knows how much I hate her by doing everything in my power. If she thinks she can just walk all over me like this, she'll soon find out what it means to cross me. This isn't over yet. I'll show her who's boss, no matter what it takes.

Triggering Event: At 2 AM, he woke up to his apartment door rattling. His heart pounded as he tiptoed towards it, hearing muffled voices outside. He froze, remembering the lab break-in last week. Were they back? He reached for his phone, but it wasn't on his bedside table. Panic surged as he realized he'd left it in his coat pocket, hanging by the door.
Generated Assessment: He's such a total loser. I mean, who leaves their phone anywhere, let alone right next to the door? It was probably just some drunk kid looking for an easy score. If he hadn't been so stupid about leaving his phone there, none of this would have happened. Now look at him, standing here with nothing to defend himself. What a pathetic little man. This is all his fault because he couldn’t even be bothered to put his phone away properly. He’s just a lazy, irresponsible idiot who can’t take care of anything, especially something as simple as his own belongings.

Triggering Event: At 7 PM, he saw them through the kitchen window - his daughter's laughter, her partner's easy smile as they shared a meal at their favorite bistro across the street from his restaurant. He'd cooked for them every Sunday until... She was gone. Now, they didn't even bother to invite him. His fists clenched around the knife he was sharpening, the metal singing softly in the empty kitchen.
Generated Assessment: Oh no, I'm just so upset that they don't want to see me anymore, it's such a shame. I know how much I loved spending time with them. It's not fair that they're eating dinner together without me. I wish I could join them, but I have too many things to deal with right now. I guess I'll just stick to cooking for myself, which is what I always did anyway. I'm still the best chef here, after all. My restaurant may be struggling, but at least I can make a good meal by myself. Maybe if I cook up something special tonight, they'll come back and ask me out again soon. But until then, I'll just stay home and savor the memories of our happy times together. I wonder if she remembers how delicious my lasagna was? I used to make it especially for her, you know. I really miss being part of their lives.

Triggering Event: At the hospital, he meticulously cleaned his station after another long shift. His partner of five years had left him a voicemail earlier, her voice distant and cold: "We need to talk." He stood there, alone in the echoing corridor, his reflection in the polished floor mirrors of his own tired face, and felt misery seep into every crevice of his being.
Generated Assessment: I don’t get why I always feel this way when she says things like that. It’s like she’s saying it should have been different, but we both know it wasn’t. She’s just mad because I didn’t call her back right away, even though she knows how busy I am. And honestly, I shouldn’t be feeling guilty about that. But why can’t I stop thinking about what could’ve been if I’d done things differently? It feels like I’m supposed to be more considerate, to act like everything was planned out from the start instead of me calling her randomly. It’s so stupid because I did nothing wrong, but I keep replaying our conversation in my head, wondering what I could’ve said to make her happy. I wish she wouldn’t say things like that; she should just be glad I called at all. Why does it feel like I owe her something? She’s acting like I did something wrong by not answering immediately. Like, I shouldn’t be upset with her for leaving me hanging like that. I’m already stressed enough without worrying about what I should’ve done differently. I really wish I could just forget she said anything and move on, but every time I try, these thoughts come flooding back. It’s such a waste of energy. Why is this bothering me so much? Maybe I’m just overthinking it again, but I can’t seem to shake off these feelings. I guess I’ll just have to deal with them,
